fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
* Change your date picker formats to:
 | jira.date.picker.java.format | MMM d, yyyy |
 | jira.date.picker.javascript.format | %b %e, %Y |

* Go to the project versions page and add a version with a release date:

!release version.png!

* When you try and release this version the release date is pre-populated with an invalid value (wrong format).

!release date.png!

Since this column is a date picker we need to use the date picker format that is configured (both in the versions table and in the release version dialog).
fields.summary: Release date using wrong formats in version management screen

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30201].
  {panel}

When I am trying to chnage the project template from default to Scrum, it throws following error.

 Changing Template - Scrum 
The currently selected issue type scheme for this project is not compatible with the GreenHopper Scrum Issue Type Scheme.

Please migrate to the GreenHopper Scrum Issue Type Scheme by associating your project via Issue Types in the JIRA Administration console. Contact a JIRA Administrator to perform this migration.
fields.summary: Please change the BackTester (BTR) JIRA project  to use Greenhoper's Sprint Agile method of planning the board
Allow reordering of Move Issue screen fields
Allow disabling of save-on-blur for inline editing
Log work via REST API for a given user
Activity Stream using French language throws a javascript error in IE8

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# In General Configuration, set the Default Language to German
# Set the User Preference language to German
# Create an issue with an Original Estimate
# Log some work against the issue
# In the Time Tracking section, the times are shown in English:
!TimeTracking.png!
# The same problem happens in the GreenHopper Classic Planning Board:
!GHS.png!

Because of this behaviour in JIRA, GreenHopper is affected as well.
fields.summary: Time Tracking Used English While User Preference and Default Language is German

fields.description:
I am trying to implement certain business rules using Jyhton scripts in the post function of a workflow. Certain decisions need to be made on the old and new values of certain issue fields. I am using the issue.getModifiedFields() method to get the old and new values. However, the method is returning an empty map because of which I am unable to access the old values. 

The same method however returns all the modified values when used in the validation script of the workflow. 

The same script is working fine in Jira 4.2.4
fields.summary: issue.getModifiedFields() returning an empty Map in workflow post function

fields.description:
!working.png!

The above button *no longer* appears, but it is there. Clicking on the same position it used to be will maximize the gadget.

Happens in Firefox 16, Safari, Chrome 22, IE8 and IE9.
fields.summary: Maximize button for gadgets is missing

fields.description: I added a comment in the existing issue, as a result system reloads the page but disappears the 'Drag and Drop' zone.
fields.summary: On updating something in any issue, system disappears the 'Drag and Drop' zone.
Change docs to tell database setup to be case sensitive
Enable Garbage Collection logging as a default with new JIRA installations
Support tools plugin is not enabled in OnDemand anymore

h3. Steps to Reproduce:

# Connect JIRA to AD.
# Add a user in AD.
# Log into that user in JIRA.
# Create a filter and share it on a project level.
# Delete the user from AD.
# Synchronise in JIRA.
# Change the ownership of the shared filter in JIRA. NPE will be thrown.
# Attempt to delete the filter and another exception will be thrown (as in the notes section).

h3. Expected Results:

Any of the following:

* The filter is deleted with the user (this is how it works for the JIRA Internal Directory).
* The filter can be assigned without the exception.
* The filter can be deleted without error.

h3. Actual Results:

NPE was thrown in browser and {{catalina.out}}.

(i) If the filter is shared with all users the exception is not thrown.

h3. Notes:

Attempting to delete the filter will result in the below exception:

h3. Workaround

# Add the deleted user to the JIRA Internal Directory.
# Change the ownership of the filter or delete it.
# Remove that user from the Internal directory.

Alternatively, the user can be added to and then deleted from the JIRA Internal Directory. When the user is deleted, the filter will be deleted.

(!) The recommended action for user management within JIRA is to [deactivate|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Users#ManagingUsers-Deactivatingauser] the user, rather than deleting it.
fields.summary: Cannot reassign project specific filters if the original owner has been deleted

fields.description:
The One and Two Dimensional hit collector classes use the ReaderCache to cache document field values.

With the introduction of Lucene 3.2 these classes should have been changed to cache against the segment readers that are passed to the setNextReader() method.

Without this change they continue to eat huge globs of memory as they always did.
fields.summary: One and Two Dimensional Hit Collectors should cache their values against the segment readers, not the directory reader

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30179].
  {panel}

This addresses a scenario in enterprise environments with multiple instances, assuming that federated search is in place (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-22590).

If the user is executing a federated search while accessing an instance (A), he probably will see issues in a search result, which are hosted in a remote instance B.

The user should now be able to edit any issue in the result set without switching instances. Issues from the remote instance should be fully editable through the edit issue overlay. 

Only if the user opens the issue details page, this should redirect him to the remote instance.
fields.summary: As a user, I can edit an issue in JIRA instance A, while working in instance B, so that I do not need to figure out, in which instances my projects reside in
As a user, I can create/clone/move an issue in JIRA instance A, while working in instance B, so that I do not need to figure out, in which instances my projects reside in

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30168].
  {panel}

Assuming a user wants to upgrade to JIRA 5.1.x, he/she would first take a look at [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA051/Upgrading+JIRA].

There, in the [Before You Start|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA051/Upgrading+JIRA#UpgradingJIRA-1.BeforeYouStart] section, it is mentioned:

{quote}
If you have installed any additional JIRA plugins (i.e. not included with JIRA), please verify that they will be compatible with the version of JIRA you are upgrading to. You can find a plugin's compatibility information from the the plugin's home page on the Atlassian Plugin Exchange. Once you have confirmed the availability of compatible versions, you should upgrade your plugins after successfully upgrading JIRA. This can be done via the 'Plugin Repository' in your Administration Console.
{quote}

However, in Atlassian Support we still get a lot of upgrade issues coming from incompatible plugins when our friends go for an upgrade. Some of them can be resolved by Atlassian Support, others need to be deflected to the plugin developers as, even though we want to help our friends, it is not possible for us to provide support for a third-party plugin we have no control on.

In that direction, could we perhaps edit the upgrade pages so that the following two points are mentioned:
* *Before* an upgrade, the JIRA administrators should use the JIRA Update Check (_Administration > Plugins > JIRA Update Check_) in order to see if some plugins are compatible with the target version or not. (We should make that more obvious as it seems to be missed).
* Regarding the third-party plugins (the ones that are not supported by Atlassian-this should be mentioned in the Atlassian Marketplace) the plugin developers should be contacted instead of Atlassian Support.

The results of this could be two-fold:
# Customers' time would be saved in the sense that plugins would be checked before the upgrade (sparing them the frustration of things not working)
# Customers' time would be saved also in the sense of contacting the right person (plugin developers) instead of coming to Atlassian Support and us trying to help, then redirecting them to the third-party plugin developers.

We are here to help our friends in every step of the way. However, perhaps changing our documentation a bit could make more sense and spare them some time.

It seems we actually have everything in [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/UPM/Checking+Add-on+Compatibility+with+Application+Updates] but it is difficult to find and I don't know how many people would look for it when upgrading.
fields.summary: Point out the JIRA Update Check and third-party plugins in our upgrade documentation

*Note:* This bug also occurs when a user in LDAP does not belong to any group. It does not necessarily have to be internal users.

fields.description:
In certain cases when older versions of JIRA (3.x) are upgraded to 4.x , during the reindexing process users may receive the following error:
{noformat}
012-10-18 15:37:32,757 issueIndexer:thread-2 ERROR user1 54467x282x1 116rbdw /secure/admin/jira/IndexReIndex.jspa [issue.customfields.impl.AbstractSingleFieldType] More than one value stored for custom field id 'customfield_10001' for issue 'DW-01'. Values [test , test ]
{noformat}

I've been told that this error message should really be a {{WARN}} in the log files as it should not affect JIRA performance.  
Can we get this error message updated as there are many cases of this coming up.  Currently the "workaround" is to manually delete database entries as proposed by https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-12796?focusedCommentId=88105&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-88105.

It would be nice for this to be included in the upgrade tasks as this is a common place where the issue seems to come up.
fields.summary: Updating the More than one value stored for custom field id ERROR to a WARNING Message

The JIRA documentation for deactivating users says,
bq. Will not receive any email notifications from JIRA, even if they continue to remain the assignee, reporter, or watchers of issues.

However, when users have been marked as inactive they are not excluded from emails sent to groups via the 'Send Email' function from within the Administration screens.

Suggest that inactive users are excluded, or administrator is given the option to exclude inactive users from email

Workaround  :
Remove user from all groups. This would prevent JIRA from sending emails to this user when sending email to a group.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30144].
  {panel}

When performing a bulk update of issue links, it may be useful to opt-out of indexing to delay the re-index operation until the operations have been completed.

A use case for this is in GreenHopper's Story -> Epic association code. We have an issue link for a Story to an Epic, and when re-assigning a list of stories to another epic we have for each story:

* Remove the issue link for the existing epic, which re-indexes the story and old epic
* Add the issue link for the new epic, which re-indexes the story and new epic.

This causes two re-indexes on each story, and a re-index on the new epic for each story associated with that epic, as well as potentially multiple re-indexes on the old epic if more than one of the selected issues are currently assigned to the same epic.

(Due to another issue we are forced to re-index the epic another time after this, due to not re-indexing after changing the updated date, which adds even more overhead)

If we could opt out of indexing, we could collect the series of issues that require re-indexing as we go, and perform a single re-index per issue touched.
fields.summary: Allow calls to IssueLinkManager#createIssueLink and #removeIssueLink to opt-out of indexing

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30135].
  {panel}

We see the following pattern in On Demand:

An email is sent to JIRA which JIRA is not able to process because the username is not on the system.  This is typically due to a mistyped email address in the admin Gui, a message from an autoreply or other automata to JIRA.

JIRA then replies to that email with a notification that the user is not in the system.  When this reply notification hits the On Demand external MX servers, a delivery attempt is made and this fails (eg, if the message was from postmaster@ and the demote system is misconfigured and does not accept postmaster email).  This email then bounces and JIRA does not deal with the bounce, leaving it in the mailbox, or worse it generates another notification causing a mail loop.

Suggested Resolutions:

* Have JIRA only email an invalid address once
* Have JIRA set a hashed reply to address to monitor the source of bounces and use it to tie it back to the sent email and disable the user/notify the admin.
** Note, this will require work from Hosted Infrastructure in order to support
fields.summary: Jira sends emails that result in bounces and it does not deal cleanly with them

fields.description:
If I type something into a field, then try to navigate to a different page without processing the data, JIRA helpfully pops up a *Confirm Navigation* dialog that makes sure that I really did mean to trash that info.

JIRA also does that for text entered into the search field, and that is wrong. Search text is disposable, and for various reasons related to UI norms, it is almost impossible that someone would inadvertently lose text they typed into a search box by inadvertently clicking on a link or browser navigation button.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30128].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 18-Dec-2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hello everyone!

Since this bug report was originally raised a while ago, and for a version of Jira that is no longer supported, we performed tests to validate the scenario and found that in Jira 7.3.9 (currently the minimum version supported) as well as in the latest Jira 7.13

The behavior provided is that the decimal separator applied will be the one corresponding to the language that the user has set in the user profile. For example, if you change the user profile to Deutsch ([^profile-language.PNG]), the decimal separator will be "," (comma) and the dot will be the digit group separator (or thousands separator) which is simply ignored; logging work for "1,5h" (one, comma, five) will result in _1 hour, 30 minutes_ and if the same user changes his language to English or Spanish( both use dot as decimal separator), the same "1,5h" will result in _15 hours_ (see example: [^logged work.PNG]). The limitation of this behavior is that the decimal separator is tied to the language.

Now that the expected behavior is explained, we will close this bug report as obsolete and since we see value in the possibility of having the decimal separator being configurable so we have created a Feature request JRASERVER-68599 Allow configuring decimal separator.

In case you have additional scenarios where this behavior is inconsistent, please raise a support request for our support team to analyze and determine the next steps.
* You can raise a support request from [https://support.atlassian.com/contact/]

Best regards,
René Chiquete - JAC Champion.
{panel}

When using the "Log work" feature, Jira will ignore comma as decimal separator, thus "7,5" is registered as "75".
If this situation is not caught before the next day, the burndown chart will look very inacurate and have reduced value.

I would like to see such input  either accepted as decimal separator OR treated as an invalid input.

*Step to reproduce*:
# install JIRA
# set the default language to English
# create issue and log work using "7,5h"
# (bug) 75 hours will be logged into the issue

Desirable result: 7.5 hours to be logged on or JIRA throws ERROR indicating invalid input
fields.summary: "Log work" ignores decimal separator

fields.description:
I have to call a JAX-WS 2.0 Webservice from a v2 plugin post-function. The complete client runtime for JAX-WS 2.0 ist included in the JRE6 which is the basis for JIRA 5.0.7. Calling the Webservice fails with 

{noformat}
2012-10-16 12:59:37,059 http-6080-1 ERROR admin 779x1071x1 164g5xi 10.21.190.45 /secure/QuickCreateIssue.jspa [spu.jira.projektzeit.CreateProjektFunction] RuntimeException
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: interface com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider is not visible from class loader
	at java.lang.reflect.Proxy.getProxyClass(Proxy.java:353)
	at java.lang.reflect.Proxy.newProxyInstance(Proxy.java:581)
	at com.sun.xml.internal.ws.client.WSServiceDelegate.createEndpointIFBaseProxy(WSServiceDelegate.java:630)
	at com.sun.xml.internal.ws.client.WSServiceDelegate.getPort(WSServiceDelegate.java:331)
	at com.sun.xml.internal.ws.client.WSServiceDelegate.getPort(WSServiceDelegate.java:313)
	at com.sun.xml.internal.ws.client.WSServiceDelegate.getPort(WSServiceDelegate.java:295)
	at javax.xml.ws.Service.getPort(Service.java:92)
	at de.continentale.vp.webservice.projektzeit.WebService100.getWebService100(ProjektzeitService100.java:58)
{noformat}

Some analysis: I did try to load the Interface com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider by different Classloaders just before calling the Webservice:
{code}
    final Thread currentThread = Thread.currentThread();
    final ClassLoader origCCL = currentThread.getContextClassLoader();
    LOG.error("origccl="
            + origCCL.loadClass(
                "com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider")
                .toString());

    ClassLoader c1 = com.atlassian.jira.issue.Issue.class.getClassLoader();
    LOG.error("System Classloader="
            + c1.getSystemClassLoader().loadClass(
                "com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider")
                .toString());
    LOG.error("Issueclassloader="
            + c1.loadClass(
                "com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider")
                .toString());
{code}

This gives the following Log:
{noformat}
2012-10-16 13:09:50,141 http-6080-6 ERROR admin 789x1273x1 164g5xi 10.21.190.45 /secure/QuickCreateIssue.jspa [spu.jira.web.WebClient] origccl=interface com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider
2012-10-16 13:09:50,141 http-6080-6 ERROR admin 789x1273x1 164g5xi 10.21.190.45 /secure/QuickCreateIssue.jspa [spu.jira.web.WebClient] System Classloader=interface com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider
2012-10-16 13:09:50,141 http-6080-6 ERROR admin 789x1273x1 164g5xi 10.21.190.45 /secure/QuickCreateIssue.jspa [spu.jira.web.WebClient] Issueclassloader=interface com.sun.xml.internal.ws.developer.WSBindingProvider
{noformat}

so, all Classloders (the current ContextClassLoader, the SystemClassLoader and the Classloader of the Class Issue) can lookup the Interface.

Probably, it is a classloader mixup.

A support call (JSP-140545) was not really conclusive (out of scope for support, but did try to help, nonetheless). The Classloader workaround shown in JRA-29896 does not work (as you can see above). And there are some questions on answers.atlassian.com concerning this problem, all of them have no real solution:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/44457/implement-jax-ws-in-jira-5-plugin
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/94094/jira-consume-soap-wsbindingprovider-not-visible
fields.summary: JAX-WS 2.0 Webservices can not be called from v2 plugins because of classloader problems

  {panel}

I would like to be able to view the following metrics from Zephyr on the JIRA Dashboard via a Gadget:
 
a. Test Case Execution Metrics would be the major one, to give all stakeholders an view to what stage QA are at with a particular release
b. Overall Defect Distribution by Status Metric - very important chart also
c. Test Case Distribution by Phase - also important
 
How would you quantify the return on the work involved in setting this up?
 
In my organisation Zephyr was only purchased for the QA team and was carefully chosen for it's integration with JIRA which will be used by other stakeholders in the organisation that would not have the where withall, nor the interest to (nor would be allowed to) login to the QA Testing Framework to get access to these metrics. It was therefore a requirement to be able to export metrics to JIRA for this purpose. It has been stated that "Zephyr offers comprehensive and unique 2-way integration with both JIRA 4.x/5.x", if this is the case would it not be very little effort to create a gadget to display these metrics?
 
In my case there would be no loss to the viewing of the Zephyr Dashboard because these stakeholders would not have access to it, in fact I thibnk it would be a gain to Zephyr to be a viewable gadget on JIRAs dashboard and would expose Zephyr to alot of people that would not have heard of it before.
fields.summary: Support for Zephyr Metric Gadgets from Zephyr Enterprise Edition 4.1

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30103].
  {panel}

When JIRA checks email on a POP server, it processes email which has an Issue Key or an In-Reply-To header and adds that email as a comment to the issue.

In addition, it is possible to set up an email handler which will turn a new inbound email into an issue in a selected project.  This needs to be set up.

When this email handler is not set up, JIRA will scan the inbox and process any email that it can and leave the rest in the pop box.  This causes an issue in On Demand (and I believe in Enterprise) because there are a number of emails which will end up in the POP mailbox that JIRA will not process.  This count of emails grows and it sucks up resources because JIRA pop's its email once every 60 seconds, scanning this whole list every 60 seconds.

Examples of these include:

* Auto Replies
* Bounces
* Spam

To resolve this issue, I suggest setting up a default handler in JIRA which deletes any messages that JIRA does not know how to process from the mailbox so that it doesn't grow over time.
fields.summary: JIRA in OnDemand should have a default mail handler that removes unprocessed messages

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-30099].
  {panel}

The tasks I have (actually via Rest API currently) in a project containing issues for version branches 1.x.x and 2.x.x:

* _Find all issues in the latest released version 1.x.x of project ABC_
* _Find all bugs in versions 1.x.x which are unresolved (known issues filter)_
* _Find all issues fixed in version 1.x.x_

As both branches are continuously released the version management in Jira resembles to this:

* 2.0.3-SNAPSHOT (next 2.0 release)
* 1.0.13-SNAPSHOT (next 1.0 release)
* 2.0.2 (latest release)
* 2.0.1
* 1.0.12 (latest 1.0 release)
* 1.0.11
* 2.0.0
* ...

My only idea: JQL should support fuzzy matching for versions. Examples for the three examples above:

* _Find all issues in the latest released version 1.x.x of project ABC_
{code}
project=ABC
  AND fixVersion in latestReleasedVersion("ABC","~1.")
  AND resolution = Fixed
{code}
I think it makes most sense here to extend the JQL function {{latestReleasedVersion}}. If the fuzzy operator should be part of the string I don't know. I think the assumption is totally valid that all strings specified here are for fuzzy matching so the prefix could be skipped. Unclear: How to extend latestReleasedVersion to find all released 1.0 versions across all projects? Perhaps: {{latestReleasedVersion("*","~1.")}}
* _Find all bugs in versions 1.x.x which are unresolved (known issues filter)_
{code}
project=ABC
  AND type=Bug
  AND (affectedVersion in releasedVersions("ABC","~1.")
    OR affectedVersion is empty)
  AND resolution = Unresolved
{code}
* _Find all issues fixed in version 1.x.x_
{code}
project=ABC
  AND fixVersion ~ "~1."
  AND fixVersion in releasedVersions("ABC")
  AND resolution = Fixed
{code}
alternatively:
{code}
project=ABC
  AND fixVersion in releasedVersions("ABC","~1.")
  AND resolution = Fixed
{code}

As you can see most of the time (for my use cases) it is sufficient to extend the JQL functions {{releasedVersions()}} and {{latestReleasedVersion()}}.

If it is easier to implement a new JQL function than you could introduce: {{matchesVersion("ABC", "1."}}. So for example the last JQL query would look like this:
{code}
project=ABC
  AND fixVersion in releasedVersion("ABC")
  AND fixVersion in matchesVersion("ABC", "1.x")
  ...
{code}

But I think this approach will not work nicely for to find the latest released version.
fields.summary: JQL: Allow fuzzy matcher for versions (fixVersions, affectedVersions)

fields.description:
After importing a standalone backup and moving and issue from one project to another, the attachment link(s) is/are updated to the new directory/issue ID, but the files themselves did not get moved to this directory. In fact, they are just removed.

Steps to reproduce

1. Using a standalone version, which has 3 projects (ProjecA ; ProjecB and ProjectC), create an issue in ProjectC using attachments
2. Create a backup from this instance and perform a search and replace to change the ProjectC name.
-- *From* ProjectC *To* ChandedC .
-- *From* PROJC- *To* CHANC
3. Change the attachment folders names as the previous step.
4. Import this XML backup in AOD instance, which attachments

After that, try to browse the same issue. All the attachments seems to be properly working, but after moving to another project, JIRA is not able to find them anymore.
Everything seems to work smoothly if we try to move an issue (with attachments) from a project not "renamed" (search and replace)

Cheers,

Paulo Renato
fields.summary: Lost attachment after moving an issue

fields.description:
When a user is deleted from LDAP, if he/she has any individual project roles in JIRA, you cannot remove the user from the project roles. You will get the "User does not exist" error when you attempt to do so.

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Create a LDAP User
# Sync the LDAP User into JIRA
# Add the LDAP user to a project role (Administrators, Developers or Users)
# Remove the LDAP User from LDAP
# Sync the LDAP Directory again in {{JIRA Administration >> Users >> User Directories}}
# Try to remove the LDAP user from the project role (you will get the User Does not Exist Error)

h3.Workaround
Simply restart JIRA, which will auto-remove the user from the project role
fields.summary: User Doesn't Exist Error When Trying to Remove an External User From a Project Role

fields.description:
A bit sketchy, but I have reproduced this reliably under the following circumstances:

# Have a plugin which defines a Custom Field Searcher, that when initialised in code blows up (unsatisfied dependency in constructor, for example)
# Start JIRA with that plugin
# Go to add a Custom Field
# Choose any type (e.g. Date Time)
# Advance to the "details" screen

When you get here, if you look in JIRA logs, you'll see that something blows up. After this, you can continue to add your custom field instance fine, but when you're done and you're back on the list of Custom Fields, you'll see the new one in the list *twice*.

Confirmed this on 5.1.6 and 5.2-SNAPSHOT. Did not happen on 5.0.
fields.summary: Create Custom Field makes TWO custom fields if there is a bad plugin searcher around

fields.description:
STEPS TO REPLICATE:

# Turn on the Wiki Renderer for the description field
# Set up a mail handler to create issues from a default reporter (i.e. so that emails from unregistered users can be turned into issues)
# Send an email through to that mail handler from an unregistered email address

RESULT:

An issue is created with the following text in the header:

{noformat}
